flow.descriptionCdata:
75fd7b44-32ec-45a5-a7f9-39387898a1cb.0673471d-a756-4f7b-87c3-bf737f560db1.description=

Displays a message to the user.

Inputs\:
  message - The message text to display
  title - The title on the message window. Defaults to "Status message".

Responses\:
  Always returns success.

Examples\:
  In order to display the message "Finished" to the user, go to the 
  detail screen for the input named "message" and change the Otherwise option
  from Prompt User to Use Constant.  Then enter the text "Finished" into the
  Constant Value field.

  References to flow variables in the Contant Value field are expanded so that
  the text may be dynamic.  Flow variable references are of the form
  ${variable}.  For example, the text\:
     ${count} systems were modified 
  could be used to display a message about the number of systems that were
  repaired, whose value is in the flow variable "count".

  When the message is displayed, it will properly render any embedded html
  tags, which permits creating messages with more advanced formatting.  For 
  example to display a message in italics you could use\:
    This is important
  or to display a message in red\:
    This is really  important

  You can create messages that contain multiple lines by entering a multiple
  line message in the Constant Value field, or by using HTML 
 tags for line
  breaks.  Note that \n characters are displayed literally and are not used for
  creating multiple lines.
75fd7b44-32ec-45a5-a7f9-39387898a1cb.0e2b0771-969a-42a1-aad0-33e4b6cd6d81.prompt=Enter a ZIP code\: 75fd7b44-32ec-45a5-a7f9-39387898a1cb.4a9dba65-1cad-4c1e-90b6-83fd68426c90.description=
This subflow was created by the Web Services Wizard to invoke the NDFDgenByDay operation on http\://graphical.weather.gov/xml/SOAP_server/ndfdXMLserver.php?wsdl. Note that the inputs to this flow which correspond to web service inputs are optional inputs.  This is due to the fact that web services definitions usually incorrectly indicate that too many inputs are required, and mirroring those settings in the flow would force you to enter unused values when running the flow.  The xmlTemplate input on the Invoke Method 2 step of this flow contains a template of the xml message to be sent, and the fields preceded by the comment "<\!--Optional\:-->" or "<\!--zero or more repetitions-->" are those which the web service indicates are optional; all others are indicated to be required.

Inputs\:
    webserviceHost - The host that is running the web service
    webservicePort - The port on the host running the web service
    headers - The list containing the headers to use for the request separated by new line (CRLF).The header name - value pair will be separated by "\:".
Format\: Conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).
Examples\: Accept-Language\:en
    proxy - The port on the host running the web service.
    proxyPort - A port on the proxy to connect to.
    NDFDgenByDay.Unit - The input named NDFDgenByDay|Unit of the complex type\: NDFDgenByDay
    NDFDgenByDay.format - The input named NDFDgenByDay|format of the complex type\: NDFDgenByDay
    NDFDgenByDay.latitude - The input named NDFDgenByDay|latitude of the complex type\: NDFDgenByDay
    NDFDgenByDay.longitude - The input named NDFDgenByDay|longitude of the complex type\: NDFDgenByDay
    NDFDgenByDay.numDays - The input named NDFDgenByDay|numDays of the complex type\: NDFDgenByDay
    NDFDgenByDay.startDate - The input named NDFDgenByDay|startDate of the complex type\: NDFDgenByDay

Results\:
    document - The raw XML response of the web service
    documentStripped - The XML response of the web service stripped of namespaces
    responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by newline.
Format\: This is conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).
Example\: Content-Type\: text/xml;charset\=utf-8
               Transfer-Encoding\: chunkedWebServiceWizard.repo.successDesc\=The SOAP command was accepted by the web service
    dwmlByDayOut - The output given by the XPath\: /Envelope/Body/NDFDgenByDayResponse/dwmlByDayOut/text()

Responses\:
    success - The SOAP command was accepted by the web service
    failure - Something went wrong while making the SOAP request
75fd7b44-32ec-45a5-a7f9-39387898a1cb.76a4a474-3329-43c3-86ac-06bedbc6e585.description=
This subflow was created by the Web Services Wizard to invoke the LatLonListZipCode operation on http\://graphical.weather.gov/xml/SOAP_server/ndfdXMLserver.php?wsdl. Note that the inputs to this flow which correspond to web service inputs are optional inputs.  This is due to the fact that web services definitions usually incorrectly indicate that too many inputs are required, and mirroring those settings in the flow would force you to enter unused values when running the flow.  The xmlTemplate input on the Invoke Method 2 step of this flow contains a template of the xml message to be sent, and the fields preceded by the comment "<\!--Optional\:-->" or "<\!--zero or more repetitions-->" are those which the web service indicates are optional; all others are indicated to be required.

Inputs\:
    webserviceHost - The host that is running the web service
    webservicePort - The port on the host running the web service
    headers - The list containing the headers to use for the request separated by new line (CRLF).The header name - value pair will be separated by "\:".
Format\: Conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).
Examples\: Accept-Language\:en
    proxy - The port on the host running the web service.
    proxyPort - A port on the proxy to connect to.
    LatLonListZipCode.zipCodeList - The input named LatLonListZipCode|zipCodeList of the complex type\: LatLonListZipCode

Results\:
    document - The raw XML response of the web service
    documentStripped - The XML response of the web service stripped of namespaces
    responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by newline.
Format\: This is conforming with HTTP standard for headers (RFC 2616).
Example\: Content-Type\: text/xml;charset\=utf-8
               Transfer-Encoding\: chunkedWebServiceWizard.repo.successDesc\=The SOAP command was accepted by the web service
    listLatLonOut - The output given by the XPath\: /Envelope/Body/LatLonListZipCodeResponse/listLatLonOut/text()

Responses\:
    success - The SOAP command was accepted by the web service
    failure - Something went wrong while making the SOAP request
75fd7b44-32ec-45a5-a7f9-39387898a1cb.fa7212c0-4bd5-4c38-98c4-a4bddd6bedf4.description=
This operation converts the date input value from one date/time format (specified by dateFormat) to another date/time format (specified by outFormat) using locale settings (language and country).
You can use the flow "Get Current Date and Time" to check upon the default date/time format from the Java environement.  

Inputs\:
    date - The date to parse/convert.
    dateFormat - The format of the input date.
Default value\: default date/time format from the Java environement (which is dependent on the OS date/time format)
Examples\: unix, yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH\:mm\:ss.SSSXXX, h\:mm a
    dateLocaleLang - The locale language for input dateFormat string. It will be ignored if dateFormat is empty. 
Default value\: default locale language from the Java environement (which is dependent on the OS locale language)
Examples\: en, ja
    dateLocaleCountry - The locale country for input dateFormat string. It will be ignored if dateFormat is empty or dateLocaleLang is empty.
Default value\: default locale country from the Java environement (which is dependent on the OS locale country)
Example\: US, FR
    outFormat - The format of the output date/time.
Default value\: default date/time format from the Java environement (which is dependent on the OS date/time format)
Examples\: unix, yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH\:mm\:ss.SSSXXX, h\:mm a
    outLocaleLang - The locale language for output string. It will be ignored if outFormat is empty. 
Default value\: default locale language from the Java environement (which is dependent on the OS locale language)
Examples\: en, ja
    outLocaleCountry - The locale country for output string. It will be ignored if outFormat is empty or outLocaleLang is empty.
Default value\: default locale country from the Java environement (which is dependent on the OS locale country)
Example\: US, FR

Results\:
    returnResult - The date in the new format.

Responses\:
    success - The date was converted.
    failure - The date could not be converted.

Notes\:
    1. If default locale language from the Java environement is English, the input dateFormat is empty and the input outFormat is empty, the input date should be in the format of "July 13, 2006 10\:04\:08 AM". If the user specifies dateFormat as "dd-MM-yyyy HH\:mm\:ss", the input date should be in the format of "13-07-2006 10\:04\:08". If the input outFormat is empty, the result will be "July 13, 2006 10\:04\:08 AM". If the input outFormat is "yyyy-MM-dd", the result will be "2006-07-13". The dateFormat for "July 13, 2006 10\:04\:078 AM" is "MMM dd, yyyy HH\:mm\:ss a".
    2. Note that the dateFormat and outFormat inputs are case sensitive. 'M' is used for months representation and 'm' for minutes.
    3. Within date and time pattern strings, unquoted letters from 'A' to 'Z' and from 'a' to 'z' are interpreted as pattern letters representing the components of a date or time string. Text can be quoted using single quotes (') to avoid interpretation. "''" represents a single quote. All other characters are not interpreted; they're simply copied into the output string during formatting or matched against the input string during parsing. The following pattern letters are defined (all other characters from 'A' to 'Z' and from 'a' to 'z' are reserved)\:

Letter	Date or Time Component			Presentation		Examples
G	Era designator				Text		AD
y	Year				Year		1996; 96
Y	Week year				Year		2009; 09
M	Month in year				Month		July; Jul; 07
w	Week in year				Number		27
W	Week in month				Number		2
D	Day in year				Number		189
d	Day in month				Number		10
F	Day of week in month			Number		2
E	Day name in week			Text		Tuesday; Tue
u	Day number of week (1 \= Monday, ..., 7 \= Sunday)	Number		1
a	Am/pm marker				Text		PM
H	Hour in day (0-23)			Number		0
k	Hour in day (1-24)			Number		24
K	Hour in am/pm (0-11)			Number		0
h	Hour in am/pm (1-12)			Number		12
m	Minute in hour				Number		30
s	Second in minute			Number		55
S	Millisecond				Number		978
z	Time zone				General time zone	Pacific Standard Time; PST; GMT-08\:00
Z	Time zone				RFC 822 time zone	-800
X	Time zone				ISO 8601 time zone	-08; -0800; -08\:00
Special case\:
unix	Unix timestamp			Number		1384326000

Examples for the date 2001-07-04 12\:08\:56 in U.S. Pacific Time\:

Date			DateFromat			DateLocaleLang	DateLocaleCountry
2001.07.04 AD at 12\:08\:56 PDT	yyyy.MM.dd G 'at' HH\:mm\:ss z		en		US
Wed, Jul 4, '01			EEE, MMM d, ''yy		en		US
2001-07-04T12\:08\:56.235+0700	yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH\:mm\:ss.SSSZ	en		US
2001-07-04T12\:08\:56.235-07\:00	yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH\:mm\:ss.SSSXXX	en		US
1309781336			unix			-		-
flow.name: Locate Forecast by Zip
